text: In other countries, this is called state capture.
author: freddydeknatel

text: From @NYTBen’s great piece on the Golan and why Trump’s announcement was “met across much of the Arab world with a shrug.”
author: freddydeknatel

text: .@kareemsakka: “The Golan was always seen as the carrot that Israel would cede for peace with Syria, and now peace doesn’t matter, Syria doesn’t matter and maybe Syria doesn’t exist at the table as the legitimate owner of the land.” https://www.nytimes.com/2019/03/22/world/middleeast/golan-heights-israel-syria.html …
author: freddydeknatel

text: “They’re critical, and cost almost nothing for the airlines to install. Boeing charges for them because it can. But they’re vital for safety.”
author: freddydeknatel

text: So much for “sovereignty.”
author: freddydeknatel

text: “Putin will use this as a pretext to justify Russia’s annexation of Crimea. The Israeli right will use it as a pretext for Israel’s annexation of the West Bank. It is a truly gratuitous move by Trump.”
author: freddydeknatel

text: The Deal of the Century is pushing a vision of Greater Israel and hoping it doesn’t provoke a regional war—or is that the goal?
author: freddydeknatel

text: So far neither Israel nor Saudi Arabia have faced serious consequences, but there is sure to be some blowback.
author: freddydeknatel

text: What quarters are you talking about? All the major news agencies are covering this. So are CNN, the BBC. Is this a criticim of the @nytimes lack of coverage?
author: freddydeknatel

text: If Pomeo didn’t call this question “ridiculous,” is it a signal?
author: freddydeknatel

text:
“If a US ambassador behaves like the high commissioner of an occupying power, he must learn that our tolerance also has its limits.” 

All’s well in the Western alliance.
author: freddydeknatel

text: Trump has avoided a major international crisis, but recognizing the occupied Golan as belonging to Israel could change that. Then again, Bibi, Bolton and others want a war with Iran and Hezbollah.
author: freddydeknatel

text:
.@BretStephensNYT must not read the AP, Reuters, CNN, BBC News, the Guardian… 

The ticket to a plum columnist post is writing about news you haven’t read.
author: freddydeknatel

text: “After the war,” in 2005 — the same year of the Haditha massacre, and of several major suicide bombings across Iraq. A year when at least 844 American troops were killed in Iraq. A year before the bombing of Samarra’s al-Askari mosque. “After the war.”
author: freddydeknatel

text: “I never thought that Iraq could ever be worse than it was during Saddam’s reign, but that is what America’s war achieved and bequeathed to Iraqis.”
author: freddydeknatel

text: .@sinanantoon: “The invasion of Iraq is often spoken of in the United States as a ‘blunder,’ or even a ‘colossal mistake.’ It was a crime.”
author: freddydeknatel

text: I wrote more about the car a few months later, and its place in the Imperial War Museum: “In a space whose mission is to honour the past while illuminating its horrors, the Baghdad car is firmly in the present, a warning of where we are.”
author: freddydeknatel

text:
I wrote this bit in 2010, when a car salvaged from a 2007 suicide bombing in Baghdad, put on display by artist Jeremy Deller, was added to the Imperial War Museum’s collection.

“At the time of the attack, 90 Iraqi civilians were being killed daily.”
author: freddydeknatel

text: This entire thread is, naturally, more lies.
author: freddydeknatel

text: champagne socialists
author: freddydeknatel

text: Why do journalists become political speechwriters and flacks?
author: freddydeknatel

text: Jared is probably hard at work directing Saudi investment in a bunch of abandoned hotels in Sinai owned by Egypt’s military.
author: freddydeknatel

text: the deal of the century!
author: freddydeknatel

text: Who thinks Trump knows what the OECD is?
author: freddydeknatel

text: “Trump and his cohort are repeating the mistakes of America’s interwar isolationists.” @StewartMPatrick has a new column in @WPReview, starting today:
author: freddydeknatel

text: “Editors and critics belong to a profession with a duty of skepticism. Instead, we find a class of journalists drunk on the gush.”
author: freddydeknatel

text: Counting down until Tablet publishes some reactionary outrage defending the original story.
author: freddydeknatel

text: .@jamesrmcd on the protests in Algeria, where “there is a deep-rooted radical popular democratic tradition. There has been a collectivity that explains their extraordinary atmosphere… a joyous rediscovery of something that was thought to have been lost.”
author: freddydeknatel
